course.subject: ECON
course.name: Economic Development and Growth
course.description: Theories of externally and internally induced growth: roles of population, human and physical capital, international trade and investment, technology, and government policies; demographic and economic transition; comparison of development strategies.
course.prerequisites: ECON 3014 or ECON 3133

reviews.author: Boeing787
reviews.title: Good Level 4 ECON Elective
reviews.comment_content:
1. Human Development
2. Poverty
3. Inequality
4. Empirical methods
5. Market Imperfections
6. Land Markets
7. Credit Markets
8. Informal Finance & Microcredit
9. Savings behavior
10. Team exercise
For the group project, we had to choose a research article out of the 6 provided and provide a critical review of the findings. The articles talk about micro credit or savings behavior in developing countries.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Sujata is a great professor. She comes prepared to class and explains the concepts well. She actually makes an effort to remember everyone's name, something that is rare amongst professors. The course content is interesting and I gained new insights in the field of development economics through her lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
This course consists of 3 written assignments, 1 video assignment, 1 group project and 1 individual essay. The assessment weightage are listed as follows:
1. 3 written assignments: 11.25% each x 3
2. 1 video assignment: 11.25%
3. 1 group project: 25%
4. 1 individual paper: 20%
5. Class participation: 10%

The grading appears to be rather laxed. Mean scores of homework assignments are well above 85. The scores for group project have not been released at the time of writing and the due date for the individual paper is on the 17th December 2021.
reviews.comment_workload:
Slightly high but appropriate for a Level 4 ECON elective. There are no midterms and finals for this course. However, the timings of the group assignment and individual paper are not ideal. The professor released a written assignment in mid November. This was followed by the group project shortly. The group project took 2 weeks to complete and we have to complete an individual summary paper to conclude the course.

All of this were released within a short span of 2 weeks and it made the workload a little unbearable. It would be better if the assignments and group projects were spaced out more. This allows us to complete the summary paper before the terms and it doesn't add on to the burden of revising for finals in other subjects.

reviews.author: boi
reviews.title: High Quality Professor
reviews.comment_content: Different aspects about developing economies and methods of tackling poverty. Not too mathy, has a nice blend of quantitative and qualitative content.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Excellent teacher, maybe the best I’ve had at UST. Everything is clear, concise, and relevant.

Difficult topics are somehow magically made easier to understand. She remembers everyone’s names and little details about them. It’s a course where you can skip 10 lectures or be dead silent every lecture and she wouldn’t mind. As far as I know, attendance is not too strict as I skipped a bunch of classes. However, if you ask questions or make comments, she’ll remember you really well and you’ll feel like you’re getting a lot more from the course.
reviews.comment_grading:
- 4 Assignments
- 1 Group Project
- 1 Individual Essay

Great. No midterms or finals, only assignments which I felt were graded quite fairly.
I got mean or slightly above mean for my assignments and got the high for the group project, overall got an A-.
reviews.comment_workload:
Little to none. Only slightly more workload during the project period but she schedules the project out well so you won’t feel overwhelmed. Assignments can be done in one day if you’re caught up, and 2-3 days if you need to catch up.

Great for balancing with other courses, good grades, little to no workload. Only a small, honest effort needed for B-range, and some minor devotion for A-range.

reviews.author: Binvant
reviews.title: One of UST's best professors
reviews.comment_content:
1. Intro to Development, HDI,
2. Poverty and Inequality
3. Empirical Methods
4. Market Imperfections
5. Land Markets
6. Credit Markets
7. Microcredit
reviews.comment_teaching: Her teaching was the best I've had at UST. She is such a good explainer - condensing complex topics into simple sentences and making it easy to understand. Even though it was through zoom, she really made a good effort. Class participation was encouraged and you didn't feel bored sitting in class at all. The style of teaching was also not just limited to lectures/textbook, but analysing real journal papers from the past decade about topics in the field. This felt like a very fresh/relevant way to study the material and it really gave you a deep understanding of the topics, especially Microcredit. I feel like I walked away with some real skills, regarding empirical research methods and anaysing/reading journal papers. This is a must take class for econ/ecof/maec majors!
reviews.comment_grading:
Class participation, 4 assignments and a group project.

Pay attention in class, put in the effort, and you'll get a good grade, simple as that. Some people complained that she was a little strict but I didn't find that at all. Make sure to take the feedback she gives from the first round group presentation and apply it to your final presentation.
reviews.comment_workload: Quite a bit, but fair amount for a 4000 level class. There are no exams, only assignments and a group project, but these still require lots of time/effort, and even then, the mean would be around somewhere in the 75% range. The assignments would take a few days to complete, and the paper/journal analysis took much longer - about 1 week. The group project is also quite time consuming, but since the assignment is pretty straightforward (analyse a journal paper related to microcredit or savings), there is no worry for freeriding.

reviews.author: HH
reviews.title: One of the best professors I've had
reviews.comment_content:
Measurement of human development, poverty and inequality,  barriers to development with a focus on land, credit and insurance markets, education and health.

The group self-study requirement will allow you to explore in greater depth one particular topic, even if it is not discussed in lectures. Self study topics: agriculture, education, health, conditional cash transfers, networks, remittences, the resource curse, fair trade, corruption, energy, informality, slums.

Very interesting course with interesting topics.
reviews.comment_teaching: This professor is one of the best professors I've had teach me at this university. She is very good at engaging a class. Leaving the class, I could tell you exactly what I had learnt. She is also very nice and supportive. She goes through the content and material very clearly. Highly recommend her!
reviews.comment_grading:
Class Participation 5%
With the smaller class size that we had, it was not difficult to discuss. Ask questions, try to answer her questions.

Open-book Quizzes 40%
The questions were not what you would expect. Even though its open book, prepare for these quizzes!

Group Self-study 30%
You pick one of the self study topics in the groups, there's a list of literature provided and you present that topic to the class. Two presentations, judged on improvement of 2nd presentation from 1st. Relaxed, nothing too stressful.

Final Exam/Closed-book Quiz 25%
Was fine.
reviews.comment_workload: Appropriate workload for a 4 credit course.

reviews.author: cyh
reviews.comment_content:
Inequality
empirical methods
land markets
credit markets
market imperfections
informal finance&microcredit
saving behaviors
reviews.comment_teaching:
The prof prepares a lot for her teaching. But there are few contents in her slides. You need to take important notes by yourself.
Her speaking speed is a little fast.
Participation is highly encouraged by raising or answering questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
class participation 10%
assignment 45% (3 writing asgns and 1 video)
group project 25%
critical analysis 20%
reviews.comment_workload:
Terrible workload...
Every time the assignment will take at least 4 hours if you want to do well. There are about 15 questions in one assignment, including a few calculations and lots of subjective questions. At the end of the sem, in addition to the group project, you need to read 3 research papers (50 pages each) and write a 5-page analysis...
